ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about manga and films that revolve around gender and sexuality, as well as Chinese artists.
Intersection between gender and feminist theory with art and visual culture. Lots of postcolonial discourse.
Discussed various topics relating to gender and sexuality in east asia. Good range of topics from the last century or so.

How to closely analyze images, how to apply recent discussion to readings and then use readings to build off of one another. Also learned to how to clearly and concisely explain my thinking. How to look at the development of Asian countries in relation to the rest of the world
Exposure to East Asian and diasporic artistic and cultural production through a gender and sexuality analytic
An in-depth understanding of gender students through different mediums of art found in East Asian culture.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Quincy's connections with many Chinese artists and scholars allowed us to directly interaction with them when they came as guest speakers. Super cool. Quincy is generally accommodating and very responsive to student suggestions.
Weaknesses: Quincy could have taken more of an active role in facilitating quality discussion. It felt like many students would just non sequitur a lot, so there was little dialogue or exploration of topics in great depth. The grading rubrics were simultaneously clear and not so. I think Quincy communicated expectations well, but the way in which they were graded (by Nicole) I feel is a little unfair. The primary example is that we were tasked with writing a thesis experiment. In every other class I've taken at Yale, thesis experiments/proposals have been more of an exploratory, general framing assignment with no expectation of the level of critical analysis required in an actual paper. In this class, visual analysis was expected (which makes sense), but it seems like in the eyes of the grader, it needed to be like the first 3 pages of a final paper, rather than a proposal. I really hope that this sort of thing is clarified in future terms.
Seminar was very engaging, light lectures were wonderful too. Have no complaints

Strengths: Professor Ngan is passionate about the course material and about his students' engagement.

Weakness: The syllabus could be structured better so as to ground students in frameworks regarding gender and sexuality and histories of East Asian nations that artworks will be analyzed from. Reading like Judith Butler should not be optional, rather, they should be required at the beginning to tie the course together more closely. This way, case studies regarding genres like Shojo Manga can be analyzed from a theoretical context shared by all students.
Quincy is the best!

The course benefited from Quincy's responsiveness to midterm feedback and taking a more directed approach to the discussions. The topics and readings week to week were really interesting without being overwhelming, and the guest lecturers were a really wonderful touch to the class as well

The class was very well-structured. I could learn complex discourses on gender in East Asian contemporary art practices. I really appreciate professor Quincys teaching methods. Each class was very well informed, I could check the each weeks learning lesson before the class and I could read reading materials with guidelines. He encouraged students to participate in the seminar actively in a very thoughtful manner. Professor let students to lead the conversation in the class and always wrapped up each class with such an articulated way.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Office hours could have been a little longer, like maybe 20 mins instead of 15 mins per session.
I liked the seminars being live virtual. That was the only way to successfully have the seminar.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I'd recommend it if you like very specific, strictly visual analysis-type courses. It also is definitely geared more towards people with manga and film interests. If your artistic interests are elsewhere, say literature or philosophy, then this course may not be for you.
Marvelous course. Thank you so much Quincy for making this course available to students at this school. A great time.
Yep! Its really interesting and offers a really unique syllabus. I learned a lot from Quincy and my peers.
Of course! This was a wonderful seminar with a great professor. You really engage with so many different topics on gender, sexuality, and Asian cultural issues.
Yesssss! Do not miss the chance to learn from Quincy. Hes kind and brilliant !

Yes! Interesting and relaxed class, with so much potential for excellent discussions depending on the perspectives in the class. I met some really wonderful friends in the class despite being virtual, which I think speaks to the environment that Quincy cultivates
I would strongly recommend this course to another student.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
Just the live, virtual seminar format with some office hours as well.
N/A
